home.description: This portfolio documents my internship journey as part of the Graduate Programming program at AP Hogeschool. Here, I share my experiences, lessons, and growth during my workplace learning period.
home.techDescription: This is the tech stack I’m able to work with. More will be added soon!
home.projectsDescription: Here are my key projects demonstrating my technical capabilities.
home.experienceDescription: My professional journey in the tech industry so far.
home.skillsDescription: Core competencies I bring to development teams.
home.educationDescription: My formal education in information technology.

experienceDescriptions.beego: I helped clients with basic tech issues at their homes or businesses, such as fixing computers and explaining how to stay safe online.
experienceDescriptions.digipolis: I learned the basics of ICT support by setting up computers and assisting with network setups. It was a great way to see how things work outside of programming.

about.title: Full-Stack Developer in Training
about.educationText: I’m currently studying Programming at AP Hogeschool, learning both frontend and backend development. While I enjoy the logic of backend work, I’m also improving my frontend skills to build complete applications from start to finish.
about.languagesText: I’m a native Spanish speaker, fluent in Dutch, and comfortable working in English. This helps me collaborate in diverse teams and understand technical resources in multiple languages.
about.aiPhilosophyText: I see AI as a helpful partner in coding—great for suggesting improvements and catching mistakes, while I maintain full control and understanding of my projects.
about.aiApproachText: I mainly use AI for code suggestions, improving existing solutions, and writing documentation. I’m always careful not to share private code or data with AI tools.
about.aiExample: While building this portfolio, I used AI for layout ideas and troubleshooting, but every decision and line of code is my own.
about.goalsText: I aim to become a fullstack developer focused on maintaining and optimizing existing systems. My priority is improving efficiency and functionality rather than always building new technologies.
about.goalsPhilosophy: It’s not just about creating new features, but about keeping existing systems future-proof and maintainable.
about.methodsText1: I do this by learning new technologies while deepening my existing knowledge—finding a balance between innovation and the practical application of proven solutions.
about.methodsText2: I learn through books like ‘Clean Code’ , 'Head First Design Patterns' and ‘Don’t Make Me Think,’ combined with AI-driven learning methods. I’m always looking for ways to improve code quality and maintainability.

footer.description: Documenting my internship journey at [Company Name] as part of the Programming program at AP Hogeschool.

blog.title: My Internship Journey
blog.description: Follow my adventures and lessons during my internship at the company

week1.overview: This week I focused on learning the AmoDrive coding architecture, understanding the project structure, and improving my coding style with the help of my seniors.

days.content: Today I started getting familiar with the project. I received instructions on account management and adding new projects. I also analyzed the project files and got an explanation about Storybook. It was a lot of information to take in, but I'm glad I have a better understanding of how everything works now.

Today I observed the seniors to see how they structure their components. I learned a lot about their workflow and how they organize their code.  After that, I started rewriting some components based on their advice. It took some time to get the hang of it, but I'm happy with the results.  I also spent some time working on the project's styling logic.

Today I talked with my senior about the coding rules and our project approach. We discussed our coding conventions and best practices. I also got instructions on how to use GitHub for updates. I received feedback on my work and explored some new coding methods. It was a long day, but I learned a lot.

Today I continued working on my project. I ran into some issues with GitHub, but with some help from my senior, I was able to fix most of the errors. I also reviewed some GitHub reviews and tried to incorporate the feedback into my code. It was frustrating at times, but I'm glad I made some progress.

Today I finished up a few tickets related to forms, cards, and modals. I ran into some more GitHub issues because I couldn't merge my changes. I'm waiting on my senior for clear instructions. Hopefully, I can resolve this soon and continue working on my project.

week2.title: Week 2
week2.overview: This week I really started working on AmoTrack, my new project. We're using React, PostgreSQL, Drizzle and Fastify. Sounds pretty cool, but it takes some getting used to!

days.content: Pfff, first day... and immediately a challenge! Drizzle and PostgreSQL had to be installed, and that was really a search. I had no idea where to start. Drizzle, I didn't know that yet, so I grabbed the documentation. And PostgreSQL... yeah, it's been a while too. Luckily I could also take a look at some older projects from the team, that helped. But it was quite a puzzle to get everything working.

Yes! The connection to the database is successful! And I even created my first CRUD endpoint. But it was quite a puzzle, because there was something wrong with the project's template. I didn't realize that right away. I was really searching like 'What am I doing wrong?!' And I also got feedback from the seniors on my work from last week. Plenty to do!

Feedback time! My seniors really took a close look at my work. They gave me tips on how to think more logically and how to better collaborate with their workflow. I received both compliments and comments, so that's nice. I now know what I need to work on. For example, they said that I sometimes draw conclusions too quickly, and that I should think calmly before I start coding something.

Today I created some new endpoints. But yeah, again that feedback: 'Think more logically!' and 'Use the Drizzle endpoint styling, it's much more efficient!'. I also had to figure out how to optimize my server files. Really no idea what they were talking about, haha! But I figured it out eventually. I googled a bit and watched some tutorials, and then I understood it luckily.

I'm now waiting for feedback on my other PRs. I picked up a few tickets, for example one about adding a new feature to the user interface, and one about improving the performance of the API. I've already written the code and created a PR for it, but now it's just waiting for the review from my colleagues. I feel like I'm working a bit slow, but my colleagues say it's okay. I think I'm on the right track, but working with tickets and PRs takes some getting used to. It's all new to me. Such a PR is quite exciting, because then your code is checked by someone else. But it's also educational, because you get feedback and you learn new things.

week3.title: Week 3
week3.overview: This week was finally better! I've made some progress and my work style has improved.

days.content: Still a bit frustrating, because I'm waiting for feedback on some components. But I was able to work on another ticket for AmoTrack.

There was some confusion about which coding style I should follow. One senior wanted me to focus on scalability and efficiency, the other on small steps and thoroughness. Both good choices, and I learned a lot from both.
Yes, my best day so far! Feedback on my PRs was super positive. Normally 50+ comments, now only 4 to 10, and mostly typos. I really feel like I'm getting better and more useful.
Today I finished all my tickets from week 1 and got them approved. And I also got feedback from my backend senior. I think I'll refactor the backend tomorrow.
Today I just kept working on the project and fixing bugs. continue working on the backend too!

week4.title: Week 4
week4.overview: This week I finally presented a demo to my seniors showcasing how I implemented both frontend and backend for the amoTrack project.

days.content: I noticed I hadn't added several features to the form components and implemented those today. I also discovered and fixed some bugs in the backend. Overall, it wasn't a particularly challenging day.

I'm feeling a bit stuck with the form implementation. While I have a working version, I realize I need to think more generically - what if my colleagues need it with different features? This generic approach is challenging because it takes longer to implement.
Today I focused on backend work, which I hadn't touched for about a week. Most of the day was still centered on frontend development, with nothing particularly notable to report.

It was a stressful day. My senior Manu complimented me on my progress, but I feel I can aim higher. I understand I'm still new, but I'm frustrated at how long it takes me to complete what seem like basic tasks. I'll need to study extra hours at home after work.

I presented my demo to the seniors today, and they said it was okay. I wasn't satisfied with my work - I know I could do much better. I've finally quit my weekend warehouse job, so let's see if I can dedicate more time to my project and raise the bar.

week5.title: Week 5
week5.overview: A relaxed week, focusing mainly on pull requests (PRs) and the AmoTrack frontend. Productive, yet still plenty of room for unwinding!

days.content: Working on PRs and the AmoTrack frontend. A bit of tweaking, a bit of fine-tuning.
Form updates for all projects, PRs handled, and the AmoTrack backend completed. Boom, another milestone achieved!
Progress made on PRs, a minor Git issue tackled, and the frontend further developed. Keeping busy!
Got a bit stuck with GitHub and the Azure server, but still managed to do a few PRs and make progress on the project. Felt like I could have done better, but overall a productive day.
Started a small personal project called 'Mini Mike'. An instruction set from my senior to follow his code guide. Educational and fun!

week6.title: Week 6
week6.overview: This week was all about Azure challenges, deployment issues, and a good dose of frontend work. A rollercoaster of technical adventures!

days.content: Frontend updates implemented and delved into 'chunk size reduction' in GitHub Actions for Azure. Had no clue what it meant, but I dove right in!

Continued working on tickets IAT-6 through IAT-11 and resolved the 'chunk size Azure issue'. Hopefully, this makes my senior Wimme's work much easier. Azure remains a challenge, that documentation is super boring.

Progress made on PRs, a Git issue tackled, and the frontend further developed. My colleague Precious and I also spent the whole day fixing deployment issues. Not really our job, but we decided to do it to avoid bothering the seniors and show initiative.
Spent time trying to fix deployment issues, updated AmoStyle, and focused on the AmoTrack frontend.
Back to work on AmoTrack and the Amo-styling-library. Also took the time to provide feedback on my colleague's project. Teamwork is key!
